results.title: Introducingt 2C,L: a language for numerically controlled tools
results.brief_description: Brings attention to the changing look of specialisation in machinery and how computer technology affects it. In doing so, we see that skills must be relocated so that single production becomes multiple production. Here, 2CL is a computer language that operators must learn which control machinery movement. The language is everyday English that is contracted to six letters, eg “diamet” for diameter.

results.title: Introducing the new worker
results.creator_credit: Richard Massingham, Central Office of Information and Public Relations Films
results.brief_description: A film showing the importance of a thorough introduction being given to the new worker on their arrival at a factory, so that they understand the practical routine and can settle down satisfactorily. Correct and incorrect methods of induction are illustrated.

results.title: Introducing the map
results.creator_credit: S.G. Fergusson, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: Shows how the rudiments of map reading may be learned through a simple study of local geography. Two children arrive in the country and engage in an exploring game. Three flags placed in different parts of the village are marked on a map; each flag to be found with the assistance of the map and an aerial photograph. The instructional approach throughout the film is indirect and simple.

results.title: Introducing Shakespeare
results.brief_description: This film is designed to provide a background against which Shakespeare’s life and ideas may be presented. Opens with scenes of Stratford and surrounding countryside, which formed the background to Shakespeare’s early life and work. Elizabethan London is illustrated by details of Visscher’s View of London of 1616. A full-scale model of an Elizabethan stage is shown and the use of the various acting areas described.

results.title: Introducing photography with a pinhole camera
results.creator_credit: Alexander Milsky and A M Productions
results.brief_description: A simple pinhole camera is designed and demonstrated. Developing and printing is shown. The use of different size cameras (boxes) are explained and demonstrated in animation.

results.title: Introducing O and M
results.creator_credit: Anvil Films and British Productivity Council
results.brief_description: The introduction of an organisation and methods man into a large company. Emphasises the need for a new outlook by management and staff before he can start his work, and follows the course of the O and M (Organisation and Methods) investigation.

results.title: Introducing New Zealand
results.brief_description: A survey of New Zealand showing the scenery, primary and secondary industries, cities and towns during the 1950s. Stresses that the economy of the country rested on exports of meat, wool and dairy produce. Shows some of the recreational activities of the people including football, bush walking, sailing and fishing.

results.title: Introducing music: the instruments of the orchestra
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: A film of a musical performance in which almost all the instruments of the symphony orchestra, plus others in current use today, are seen and heard in close-up. The music was composed by John Dankworth, who also conducts the orchestra and plays the saxophone. It has been ingeniously written, not only to give each instrument its moment of personal display, but to allow for frequent quieter moments during which a narration introduces the instruments and the techniques of the players.
results.title_for_label: Introducing music: the instruments of the orchestra

results.title: Introducing insects
results.brief_description: A veritable who’s who of the insect world, this film ushers you into a wonderland of nature for an absorbing study of creatures more colorful and quite as complex as much larger forms of animal life. Microcinematography, slow-motion and time-lapse, reveal startling sequences in insect development.

results.title: Introducing East Africa
results.brief_description: A survey of changes which have taken place during 50 years of British rule in East Africa. Includes modern farming methods, introduction of cattle raising and industry, water conservation, the construction of schools and colleges and hospitals, nurses and doctors bringing health to the people of the land.
